sub_title: Lecturer and researcher in European Studies at The Hague University of Applied Sciences
summary:
Ιnternational politics lecturer & analyst with expertise in energy security, foreign policy, conflict analysis and public policy crisis-management. I got my PhD  at the University of Leiden where I assessed the impact of the recently discovered gas reserves in the Eastern Mediterranean on the exacerbation of pre-existing tensions around the island of Cyprus. 
Since 2014 I have been working as a lecturer of International & European Governance at Leiden University and The Hague University of Applied Sciences. My teaching portfolio includes a variety of courses, ranging from Research Methodology and Public Policy to Politics of Crisis Management and Peacebuilding after conflict.  Teaching has helped me sharpen my communication and inter-personal skills while the pursuit of PhD has enabled me to improve my research and analytical skills. That is why I am always open to opportunities that allow me to put those skills in practice.

projects:
[{'title': 'Summer School: Module Human Security, Rights & Development at The Hague University of Applied Sciences', 'date': {'start': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2016}, 'end': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2016}}, 'description': 'This year I took over the responsibility of organizing, coordinating and teaching in the 2nd consecutive Summer School at The Hague University of Applied Sciences.
What was required from the students was to evoke and sharpen their critical thinking vis-à-vis international problems by introducing them to several topics and issues which are of significance in the fields of international relations, political economy and energy security. Lectures, workshops, class discussions, student assignments and presentations as well as visits to international organisations constitute the departing point of this “journey” that they had embark upon. ', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Vasileios P.', 'last_name': 'Karakasis, PhD', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Lecturer and researcher in European Studies at The Hague University of Applied Sciences'}]}, {'title': 'Summer School at The Hague University of Applied Sciences: Module Human Security', 'date': {'start': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}, 'end': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}}, 'description': "IIn the context of the Module that took place under the aegis of Pr. Voorhoeve and lasted two weeks, the participant students were called to develop certain competencies: recognise security challenges affecting countries and/or population groups, develop the ability to take action and the confidence to take risks in order to stimulate mutual understanding and cooperation,become familiar with the field of peace and security, transitional justice, environmental security, economic development and terrorism, while gaining an insight into the workings of international organisations, NGOs and government bodies. Adding to this, they were called to apply theory and case studies through conducting research and perform presentations on international problems that should raise our awareness.
To this effect, I undertook several responsibilities.In terms of program and content management, I established an overarching theme for each day of these two weeks (challenges to international peace and security, peace-keeping missions, terrorism, global institutions, modern development, food and water security).Furthermore, I invited lecturers to give lectures that would cover the content of each day's overarching theme and I organized workshops whose aim was to make students engage in constructive dialogue on certain topics. Students were asked to pursue presentations on a specific area by acting as UN diplomats that were authorized to raise our awareness upon an issue of their choice. The very content of each presentation was integrated in the above mentioned pre-defined overarching theme. After the end of the every-day presentations, students were called to establish ad hoc groups, and ask questions to the students that had delivered their presentation. After this process my colleague and I provided the students with individual feedback.
", 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Vasileios P.', 'last_name': 'Karakasis, PhD', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Lecturer and researcher in European Studies at The Hague University of Applied Sciences'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Saskia', 'last_name': 'Rademaker', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Policy Advisor & Researcher, The Hague University of Applied Sciences'}]}, {'title': 'UN Simulation Program in Thessaloniki, Macedonia, Greece', 'date': {'start': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2006}, 'end': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2006}}, 'description': 'Founded in 2002, ThessISMUN is the only one Model UN organised in Greece and a supportive one for UN Models in neighbouring countries, as well Regional Models in other parts of Greece.
